quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
words = ["hello"]
words.append("world")
print(words[1])
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Functions[/h1]

Another way of altering lists is using the [b]append [/b]method. This adds an item to the end of an existing list. [code format="py" codeId="319"]nums = [1, 2, 3]
nums[b].append[/b](4)
print(nums)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b][code format="raw" ]>>>
[1, 2, 3, 4]
>>>[/code]
[note]The [b]dot [/b]before append is there because it is a [b]method [/b]of the list class. Methods will be explained in a later lesson.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
letters = ["a", "b", "c"]
letters.append("d")
print(len(letters))
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Functions[/h1]

To get the number of items in a list, you can use the [b]len [/b]function. [code format="py" codeId="320"]nums = [1, 3, 5, 2, 4]
print([b]len[/b](nums))[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
5
>>>[/code]
[note]Unlike [b]append[/b], [b]len [/b]is a normal function, rather than a method. This means it is written before the list it is being called on, without a dot.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the result of this code?
nums = [9, 8, 7, 6, 5]
nums.append(4)
nums.insert(2, 11)
print(len(nums))
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Functions[/h1]

The [b]insert[/b] method is similar to [b]append[/b], except that it allows you to insert a new item at any position in the list, as opposed to just at the end.[code format="py" codeId="321"]words = ["Python", "fun"]
index = 1
words[b].insert[/b](index, "is")
print(words)[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
['Python', 'is', 'fun']
>>>[/code]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to add 'z' to the end of the list and print the list's length.
[!raw!]
list.{0}('z')
print( {1}{2} )
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]List Functions[/h1]

The [b]index[/b] method finds the first occurrence of a list item and returns its index.
 If the item isn't in the list, it raises a ValueError.[code format="py" codeId="322"]letters = ['p', 'q', 'r', 's', 'p', 'u']
print(letters.index('r'))
print(letters.index('p'))
print(letters.index('z'))[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
2
0
ValueError: 'z' is not in list
>>> [/code]
[note]There are a few more useful functions and methods for lists. 
[b]max[/b](list): Returns the list item with the maximum value
[b]min[/b](list): Returns the list item with minimum value
list.[b]count[/b](obj): Returns a count of how many times an item occurs in a list
list.[b]remove[/b](obj): Removes an object from a list
list.[b]reverse[/b](): Reverses objects in a list[/note]
